Goulais Bay Indian Mission, Ont.,
April 19th, 1909.

W.L. Nichols, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste Marie.

Dear Sir,-

We the Indians of this place, we held
the meeting on the 19th day of April, 1909, and came
to the conclusion to ask the Department for a bell for
the school his need it and small flag for the school
for Goulais Bay.

x x x x

John Dadelahbondong, Chief
and others.
Ottawa, May 5, 1908.

Sir—

Referring to the request of the Goulais Bay Indians for a bell and flag for their school, I beg to say that a flag will be sent you from the Department.

In regard to the bell, you should state whether there is a belfry on the building and also ascertain the cost, including placing it in position, provided one can be purchased locally. In giving this cost the size of the bell should be stated.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

W.L. Nichols, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of May 5th, 1907

No. 240777/5-

I have the honor to refer to your letter of May 5th, 1907 re Bell for Goulais Bay Indian School, and beg to say that a Bell complete suitable for that School can be purchased for from $165 up. One at about $165 would be suitable the cost of hanging and freight would probably cost five or six dollars more. I am not sure as to size but the size at the above price would be right and would weigh probably 100 to 125 lbs.

A Bell of the above description can be obtained through the Hardware shop here. The weight of a bell of this kind is about 105 lbs and the framework &c. to total 150 lbs.

I have the honor to be

Yours most obediently,

[Signature]

Indian Agent

The Secretary Department of Indian Affairs

Ottawa
Sir,

Referring to your letter of No.

Have the honor to report that in my last visit to Ratelton Bay I found the school house to be badly in need of painting and as the Indians also drew my attention to the fact I would suggest that I be authorized to have the building repainted.

The estimated cost of paint and labor of putting on paint is about $257.00 fairly.

Have the honor to

For your most obedient servant,

Mr. J. Nichols
Indian agent

The Secretary Department of Indian Affairs Ottawa
IN INDIAN AGENT'S OFFICE,

Sir,

Referring to your letter of

No.

I have the honor to refer the request of the Indians Bay Indians who desire work for fencing below Ground. The work will cost us the equivalent of $21.00 and I think the Indians will supply the poles and plant them and put up the fence in addition to the work. 2 gates would be required, one large one and one small one or perhaps 3 small ones. I do not know what these gates cost but the large 10 ft gate is about double the small ones and the latter are about $5 each.

I have the honor to be

your obedient servant,

W.M. Macleod
Indian Agent

The Secretary Department
of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Ottawa, August 25, 1908.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your three letters of the 20th inst., relative to certain matters in connection with the Goulais Bay school.

In reply I beg to say that you may have a bell of the kind described hung in the belfry of the school-house; the cost, including hanging, not to exceed $31.50.

With reference to the painting and fencing the Department would like to have a resolution of the Council authorizing the work to be done, and you should forward with the resolution offers to do the work by responsible Indians at stated prices. The dimensions of the building and grounds should be given.

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

W.L. Nichols, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Ottawa, 25th January, 1911.

Sir:-

I beg to say that the Department received through
the Sault Ste. Marie Indian office your account rendered
at $1.50, which is dated the 7th November, for advertising
for a teacher for the Indian school at Goulais Bay. It
is usual for all such accounts to be taxed by the King's
Printer before payment, and in order to admit of this being
done, it is necessary to have a clipping of the advertise-
ment in question to attach to the account. I shall be glad
if you will forward the clipping required at your earliest
convenience.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Ottawa, 13th September, 1911.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 9th instant, I re-enclose herewith the account rendered at $2.00 which you submitted from the Rev. J. R. Richards for an advertisement which he had inserted in the Catholic Record. It will be necessary for the account in question to be attached to voucher forms and duly certified by you. You should also obtain from Reverend Gentleman a clipping of the advertisement in question and attach it to the account. All accounts for printing or advertising have to be submitted by this Department to the King's Printer for taxation previous to payment and, therefore, a copy of the work done is required.

With respect to the payment made by Father Richards to the Pembroke Observer, I beg to say that it will be necessary for him to obtain a receipted account from that paper together with a copy of the work done. This account should be submitted in a similar manner to that above referred to, and when received here, it will be forwarded to the King's Printer for taxation.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Murdock McLellan, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste Marie, Ont.
Sir,

I have the honor to submit that I have just got prices on the cost of an iron pipe that would be suitable for the above at the Great Bay Mission, and for the depth that they expect to drive the pipe will be about fourteen inches to the side. I have not been able to get any information regarding the cost of the labor in getting it put in place.

If we decide to have one put in place, I might say that it is almost necessary to get the new Fortunate of navigation near close to our time and it is about 35 miles distant from here.

J. D. Maclean
Deputy and Secretary
Office of Indian Affairs

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Can.

Sir,

I beg leave to call your attention again to the wish of having a well dug at my school as impossible as it is impossible for us to carry water a mile or more. Unless we are furnished with a means by which we can procure water I will be obliged to give up teaching. Trusting to receive a reply by return mail.

Yours very respectfully,

Mary E. Gallagher
Goulais River
Oct.
Ottawa, December 1, 1911.

Sir,

I beg to confirm the following telegram sent you yesterday:- "May purchase iron pump for Goulais Bay School from Cochrane Hardware Company of Sault Ste. Marie."

I may say that since sending that telegram the Department is in receipt of a communication from Miss Gallagher in which she states that she will be forced to resign unless something is done to provide a proper supply of water. In view of this I would ask you to take immediate action.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Murdoch McLennan, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
Ottawa, December 1, 1911.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, and in reply I beg to say that before its receipt the Department had authorized the Indian Agent to purchase a pump for the Goulais Bay School. He is being written to today and asked to take immediate action and it is hoped that before long you will have a satisfactory supply of water.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Miss Mary E. Gallagher,
Teacher,
Goulais Bay Indian School,
Goulais River, Ont.

Ottawa, 29th December, 1911.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 23rd instant, I re-enclose herewith the account rendered at $2.00 which you forwarded from the Catholic Record for advertising for a teacher for this Department. As intimated in letter to you of the 13th September, the account should be attached to voucher form in duplicate and duly certified by you, after which it should be enclosed to the Department, and it will then be submitted to the King's Printer to be taxed, when the question of payment will be given consideration.

With reference to the payment made by Rev. Father Richards to the Pembroke Observer, I beg to remind you that the Department requires an account (which seemingly you did not forward) before the question of recouping Mr. Richards for the outlay incurred can be considered. In this case also the account should be in duplicate, and should have a clipping of the advertisement attached thereto, and should be attached to voucher form bearing your certificate.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Murdoch McLennan Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Ottawa, February 15th., 1916.

With Obedience

Sir,-

The Department has received the voucher rendered at $16.00 which you submitted recently from Miss Annie O'Connor for expenditure in connection with the Goulais Bay Mission School; and in reply I beg to transmit herewith cheque No. 4074 for $5.75 in Miss O'Connor's favor, and I beg to say that the charge of $4.50 for cleaning windows and the charge of $1.00 for cleaning chimney has been disallowed, as the allowance of $6.25 per quarter for caretaking of the school covers the paid charges. The charge made on the 15th December for cleaning stove pipes and $1.50 for banking school have been allowed, which makes a total allowance of $8.75. From this amount $3.00, which was allowed in the teacher's account for September quarter, for supplying water and splitting wood, has been deducted. This has been done owing to the fact that a separate account for $5.00 was received from Miss O'Connor covering these last mentioned charges, which account was paid. The total payment therefore is $5.75 as per cheque enclosed.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. McNabb Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste Marie, Ont.

Ottawa, April 17, 1916.

Madam,

Referring to your remarks on the return for the Goulais Bay School for the quarter ended March 31st, last, in which you suggest that the standing order still in Agent's hands for goods for Xmas tree last year, which was not used, be applied to providing games, books, blocks, sticks for construction work, etc., for children's use and to be property of the school I beg to say that the money authorized last year has now lapsed. If you will forward a requisition in the usual way for the games, books, etc., you desire the same will be considered.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Miss Annie O'Connor,
Teacher,
Goulais Bay Indian School,
Goulais Bay, Ont.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th Instant No 13-4-5 with Vouchers for A/c for Leader Store inclosed, and in reply have to say that I am enclosing a receipt for the Freight. There is not any regular Boat running to this place and we have to ship our Freight on a Fish Boat, they do not issue any Bills of Lading or Shipping Bills. They carry our Freight just to accommodate us, they do not carry freight for anyone outside of the Government, they make nominal Charge.

In reference to an explanation for $1.50 added to Blanket, I have to say that I had the Merchant call me up when they were packing the Goods, I found everything all right excepting the Blanket, I thought that I should send a heavier pair to the Teacher and when I objected The Leader man said if you give $1.50 extra I will give you a Blanket that we are retailing at $10.00 I found it was a 7lb White Woolen Blanket well worth the Difference and I told him I would take it. If the Department objects to pay the extra $1.50 I will make it good myself to the Leader, Send him his Cheque less this amount and I will explain to him the reason of the shortage.

Hoping this explanation is satisfactory and that Cheque will be forwarded at once,

ABSTRACT FROM INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON THE GOULAIS BAY SCHOOL.

September 8, 1924.

Main building with woodshed attached to it.

1. In building this school tongued and grooved clapboard was not used. Plain board overlapped was used. The whole building outside (every board) needs repainting. They are loosening and allowing the wind to get in.

2. The front steps are broken. I saw three little lads climbing into school on hands and knees. This is too much 8 times a day.

3. The whole interior walls are most forbidding. Murocco needed in classroom and paper in other rooms.

4. The woodshed needs to be properly enclosed, quite a few side boards are off.

5. The school needs rebanking and painting badly.

6. There is no cupboard or shelves to keep books and equipment.

7. School should have proper locks and key left in responsible hands.

8. Toilets in poor condition. Carpenter needed.

9. Cupboard and shelves needed to hold books and equipment.

10. Towelling, soap, pail, drinking cups, looking glass needed.

11. Fifteen combs needed badly.

12. Dutch cleanser needed to clean up utensils, etc., etc.

13. The place needs cleaning in the worst way, so much so, that this teacher would have left for Batchewana if she could have done so.

I am afraid that Mr. McNabb did little two years ago at my last visit to make the place habitable. I cannot understand why any building is allowed to practically fall to ruin. It is at present the most forbidding appearing school for a teacher to enter.

J. M. Bennett, Insp.
Ottawa, September 15th, 1924.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Goulais Bay Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the condition of the building and to the repairs required, as follows:

1. In building this school tongued and grooved clapboard was not used. Plain board overlapped was used. The whole building outside (every board) needs repainting. They are loosening and allowing the wind to get in.

2. The front steps are broken. I saw three little lads climbing into school on hands and knees. This is too much 8 times a day.

3. The whole interior walls are most forbidding. Muresco needed in classroom and paper in other rooms.

4. The woodshed needs to be properly enclosed, quite a few side boards are off.

5. The school needs rebanking badly.

6. There is no cupboard or shelves to keep books and equipment.

7. School should have proper locks and key left in responsible hands.

8. Toilets in poor condition. Carpenter needed.

9. Towelling, soap, pail, drinking cups, looking glass needed.

10. Fifteen combs needed badly.

11. Dutch cleanser needed to clean up utensils, etc.

You should arrange to have the repairs enumerated by the Inspector carried out and the building placed in a good state of repair before the extreme cold weather sets in.

The boards on the outside of the building should be nailed where required.

The front steps should be repaired.

A. H. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

The interior walls of the classroom should receive one coat of muresco.

The woodshed should be repaired and the school building banked.

A cupboard should be placed in the schoolroom in which to store books and other equipment, and proper locks with keys should be placed on the doors.

The repairs required to the toilets should be carried out.

Any other work besides that enumerated above which you consider necessary should be done. It will be necessary for you to engage the services of a competent man to carry out the repairs required to this building. The Department will reply on you to see that the work required is carried out as inexpensively as possible. You should arrange for the purchase of any material required. It will, no doubt, be necessary for you to proceed to Goulais Bay to make arrangements for the carrying out of these repairs.

You should purchase and have delivered for the use of the schoolroom 6 yards towelling, 12 cakes laundry soap, 1 galvanized water pail, 4 drinking cups, 1 looking glass, 15 steel combs and 4 tins Dutch Cleanser.

When all the repairs have been completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of any material purchased, as well as vouchers, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the labour employed, and also for the supplies which you are authorized to purchase.

The Inspector states, regarding the school building, that it is hard to understand why it was allowed to practically fall to ruin, and that it is at present the most forbidding appearing school for any teacher to enter. It is considered that you should have reported the condition of this building early in the summer in order that the repairs required could have been carried out before the school re-opened. The Department will expect you to see that both the school building and teacher's living quarters are repaired and that the supplies which you are authorized to purchase are ordered at an early date and forwarded to the teacher.

I shall be pleased to hear as to what arrangements you are making to carry out the above instructions, and the date you consider the same will be completed.

Your obedient servant,

EXTRACT FROM INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON GOULAIS BAY SCHOOL.

MAY 18, 1925.

The interior of building is positively dirty looking. The walls of classroom need to be washed and then murseco or something applied. Woodwork needs painting. Floor needs treatment. The teacher's living room and bed room need papering in the worst way. The bricks on the chimney are falling and need to be fixed as soon as possible.

The school roof is in urgent need of repairs also the woodshed. All buildings in fact need repairing.

Carpet or something should be supplied for the bedroom 10' by 7'.

Floor oil cloth is needed 10' 5" by 10'.

The mattress and bed springs are needed badly; the teacher complains of them being most uncomfortable.

Teacher's desk is falling apart. The desks and chair are needed as soon as possible. There are only two chairs in the whole building and would grace a miner's shack.

Miss Peltier deserves credit for working under conditions in Goulais Bay that were as I supposed remedied last fall.

In case Mr. McNabb is not well enough to attend to the reconditioning of this school, can it be done some other way?

Classroom desks are needed badly.

J. M. Bennett,
Insp.
Ottawa, June 1, 1925.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Goulais Bay Indian Day School, has again drawn attention to the condition of the school building and classroom. In this connection I wish to refer you to official letters of September 15, 1924, and April 8, 1925, regarding this matter. You have failed to take any action and the Department must now insist that steps be taken by you during the coming summer to have the building repaired and placed in good condition. You should arrange to have the following work carried out:

1. The walls of the classroom should be thoroughly cleaned and then murocoided.

2. The woodwork should be painted and the floor should be thoroughly cleaned and then painted or oiled.

3. The teacher's living room and bedroom should be repapered.

4. The chimney should be repaired, as a number of the bricks have fallen off.

5. The roof of the school building is in need of some repairs and also the woodshed.

The Inspector states that a rug and oilcloth are required by the teacher for her bedroom and living room, also that a new mattress and bed springs are required.

The Inspector further states that a new desk and chair are required for the use of the teacher and some chairs for the living quarters.

Please report as soon as possible whether you can arrange to have the buildings at this school placed in a good state of repair and cleaned, also if you can attend to the purchasing of a teacher's desk, chair and other furnishings mentioned. The Department will expect to hear from you at an early date as to what action you intend taking in having this work done.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

A. D. McNabb Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

Sir;

In reply to your letter of the last Instant No 13-4-5 in reference to the Goulais Bay School. I have to say that I interviewed 3 different firms of painters and only one of them Mr Smit would go to the expense of going to look at the job. I told them the day I was going up there and that I would have a boat to meet them and take them across to the Mission. Mr Smit went with me and we looked over the building very carefully and I find that the outside as well as the inside needs painting. I find also that the building needs a new roof, there is no use in patching up the roof as it is no good. I had Mr Smit submit me figures on the roof also painting the outside of the School.

I inclose his figures for the different parts, the figures may look big to you but we have to take into consideration the expense of getting the material on the ground. Mr Smit has done work for the Department hereto fore and he gave good satisfaction, and I would recommend that he be given the contract, as I am certain that we cannot get the work done any cheaper.

Awaiting your further instructions,

I have the honor to be Sir,

Ottawa, June 30th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, enclosing a communication from Harry Smit, Sault Ste. Marie, giving an estimate of the repairs, cleaning, painting and papering required to place the Goulais Bay Indian Day School and teacher's quarters in good condition.

In reply I beg to say that, while the figures quoted appear high, the Department will approve of certain of the work being carried out during the coming summer holidays. You may arrange with Mr. Smit to repair all broken plaster in the schoolroom, living room and bedroom, retint walls and ceiling and repaint with two coats all doors, windows and wainscoting and give the floors two coats of oil; also to repaper ceiling and walls of the living room and bedroom and repaint doors, windows, etc. Also repair chimney, put on new roof on woodshed and replace 4 lights of glass. The cost of this should not exceed the estimate mentioned in Mr. Smit's letter, viz: $290. The Department will also approve of the roof being reshingled with a good grade of British Columbia shingles. The cost of this work, including material, should not exceed the sum of $240.

The painting of the outside of the school house will, owing to lack of funds and the cost of the other repairs, have to stand over until next year. The Department is not prepared to authorize any expenditure at the present time in painting the outside of this building.

You should arrange to visit this school and inspect the work before it is completed and see that it is being satisfactorily done, also that a good grade of material is being used. The Department will leave the repairs and shingling in your hands to see that the work is done during the summer holidays, and that it is finished in a satisfactory manner.

When the work is completed, you should forward separate vouchers, in duplicate, stating therein the work carried out to the inside of the building, and a separate voucher, in duplicate, covering the cost of the shingles and labour in putting them on. It is understood that the above authorized amounts cover the cost of all materials, labour and freight charges.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 21st instant, relative to the repairs and redecorating required to the Goulais Bay Indian Day School building, I have to say that Mr. Agent McNabb obtained prices from a contractor at the Soc and was instructed in official letter of June 30th, last, to have the following work done:

1. Repair all broken plaster in schoolroom, livingroom and bedroom.

2. Retint walls and ceiling and repaint with two coats all doors and windows and wainscoting. - the floors to be given two coats of oil.

3. Repaper ceiling and walls of living room and bedroom and paint doors, windows, etc.

4. Repair chimney.

5. Put new roof on woodshed and reshingle the roof of the school building.

The work was to be given to Harry Smit, a contractor at the Soc. It is presumed that the agent will have this work completed before the school re-opens after the present summer holidays.

Ottawa, September 14, 1927.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Goulais Bay Indian Day School, states that the following equipment, repairs and renovations are needed at the school and teacher's living quarters:

A cupboard is needed for the storing of equipment and books. Stove pipes require to be cleaned and enamelled. There is no door on one of the toilets and they require to be thoroughly cleaned and whitewashed.

You should arrange to have the stove pipes taken down, thoroughly cleaned and replaced, and you may have them enamelled. You may also arrange to have a suitable cupboard installed in the schoolroom. This cupboard should be of inexpensive construction. The toilets should be repaired, thoroughly cleaned and placed in a sanitary condition. If you consider the same necessary, you should have them whitewashed.

With reference to the teacher's living quarters, the Inspector states that the walls of the kitchen need attention and that they should be thoroughly cleaned. You may arrange to have this work done. You may also purchase and have forwarded, for the teacher's use, 1 galvanized water pail, 2 mixing bowls, 1 tea kettle, 2 tea plates and 2 cups and saucers.

Please give the above matters your early attention, and you should see that no unnecessary expense is incurred. Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded by you covering any expenditure incurred.

The Inspector also states that the exterior of the school building needs painting. It is considered that it is now too late in the season to have this work done. You should draw this matter to the attention of the Department early next spring, giving an estimate of the cost of supplying the paint, etc., required, and in having the work done.

This school building is being painted and repaired

Ottawa, June 12, 1925.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Goulais Bay Indian Day School, states that while the school building is being painted and repaired on the outside he would recommend that the ceiling in the classroom be covered with beaver board, as it is in bad condition. He also states that the chimney needs attention and that the teacher's residence should be papered and a new floor put in.

I shall be pleased to have your recommendation regarding the Inspector's suggestions, and if you recommend that the work mentioned by him be carried out, you should give an estimate of the cost. This matter should receive your prompt attention.

Ottawa, July 12, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, estimating the quantities and the cost of the materials necessary, also the cost of the labour, in carrying out the repairs required to the interior of the Goulais Bay Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of a hardwood floor being laid in the classroom, with paper between, and the same being given two coats of oil. Further, the ceiling may be covered with beaver board and the joints covered with panel strips and the repairing and cleaning of the chimney may be carried out.

You should arrange for the purchase and delivery of the material, as mentioned in your letter, and for the labour in having the work done. You should see that all work is satisfactorily completed and that the cost of the material and labour does not exceed your estimate of approximately $125. After the work has been finished, please forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the material and for the labour. This matter should receive your prompt attention, in order that all this work can be completed before the school re-opens after the present summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF SEPARATE SCHOOL INSPECTOR GREENING, DATED MAY 14, 1931, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE GOULAIS BAY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Original on File 13-4-6.

Building is in very fair general condition, except that the teacher's quarters need papering badly.

There is no one on the reserve, however, competent to do this work and the cost of bringing a man from the nearest town (Sault Ste. Marie) would be prohibitive.

Indian Agent, teacher and inspector discussed the situation and the teacher is willing to return to Goulais Bay a little earlier (after the summer holidays) and do the work herself.

The Agent and I agree that a reasonable business proposition would be for the Department to make the teacher a grant of, say, twenty or twenty-five dollars to have the work done. She would be expected to supply the material and pay for any assistance necessary.

The teacher would be willing to accept the arrangement, and such is strongly recommended as the most satisfactory arrangement possible.

The teacher's cutlery seems to have been badly abused in past years. It is suggested that the Agent be asked to consider replacing it.

EXTRACT from Report of Inspector W.J. Greening regarding his visit to the Goulaïs Bay Indian Day School on May 21, 1932.

Original on File 13-4-6.

Particularly meritorious is the work that has been done with the children in sewing and darning, and knitting will be taken up if materials are supplied. Unfortunately, however, there is little being done for the boys outside of purely academic work. There should be a school garden. While the Agent agrees, he is rather afraid to incur any expenditure in this connection. I, personally, think that one of the most valuable things we can teach is the desire and ability to be self-supporting, and as a means to this end, the study of agriculture has a very definitely high value in Indian Day Schools. If the Department agrees, perhaps Mr. Agent Sims might be encouraged to provide some suitable land for a school garden.

I have instructed Miss Duff to requisition for some dozen or so thimbles, some knitting needles and wool for knitting and some mending yarn for darning. If the Department could, in addition, supply some material, say some flannel, for making up into undergarments, I am sure good use would be made of it.

EXTRACT from Inspector Greening's Report on his inspection of the GOULAIS BAY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL on May 22nd, 1933. - Original on File 13-4-6.

The school narrowly escaped being burned to the ground this past winter, as a result of a poor system of stove pipes.

Mr. Agent Sims and I looked over the situation. In my opinion, a hole should be cut in the ceiling of the kitchen and a second hole cut in the brick chimney and the stove pipe run into it, as, at present, the pipe is led through a high attic-like space. It was in this space that the fire broke out this winter. The space cannot be reached except by breaking in through the roof. A change in the system of stove pipes is, I believe, imperative and the Agent has taken the matter in hand.

The stove at present in use in the kitchen is entirely worn out. The oven is practically useless. Even when efforts are made to protect the food (in the oven) with sheets of tin, ashes will still fall on it. Moreover, it is most uneconomical in regard to fuel. Miss Duff kept a careful record of wood burnt this past winter and, although eggs froze in the kitchen, the kitchen stove used up twice as much fuel as did the stove in the schoolroom.

The saving in fuel would more than pay for a new stove in a couple of years and a new stove would permit of more comfort for the teacher.
Ottawa, June 5, 1933.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Goulais Bay Indian Day School, states that the school building narrowly escaped being burned during the past winter, as a result of the poor system of stove pipes. He states that, in his opinion, a hole should be cut in the ceiling of the kitchen and in the brick chimney and the stove pipe run into it, as, at present, the pipe is led through a high attic-like space. The Inspector also states that you have taken the matter in hand. The Department considers that it would be advisable, during the coming summer, to have the alteration made, in order to prevent any danger from fire. This matter will be left in your hands, to have the work done at the lowest possible expense.

The Inspector also drew attention to the condition of the stove at present in use in the kitchen, which, he states, is entirely worn out and most uneconomical in regard to the amount of fuel consumed. Please inform the Department regarding the urgency for supplying a new stove for kitchen use, and give an estimate of the cost. Our funds this year are extremely limited, and unless you consider the supplying of a new stove to be urgent, favourable consideration could not be given to authorizing the expenditure. When you estimate of the cost is received, the matter of the purchase of a new stove will be given consideration.

Your obedient servant,

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie,
Ont.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.
Sault Ste Marie, Ont.
June 29, 1933.

Sir;

Regarding a cook stove for the Goulais Bay Indian School as per your letter No. 13-4-5 Of the 5th instant, I beg to say that I have secured prices and the most suitable stove for the school would cost $51.75 plus freight to Goulais Bay. It is the same make of stove that was purchased for the Batchewana school in 1930 which has given splendid satisfaction.

As stated by Inspector Greening the old stove is practically worthless, and I would strongly recommend that a new one be purchased.

I have the honor to be, Sir
your obedient servant.

G. H. Smith
Indian Agent.

A.F. MacKenzie, Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, July 5, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, giving an estimate of the cost of a cook stove for use at the Goulais Bay Indian Day School. In this connection it is noted that the old stove at present in use is beyond repair.

In view of your recommendation, that a new stove be supplied, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase, from a firm on the list to receive consideration, of a stove. This should be of a type which you consider satisfactory. The total cost, including freight to Goulais Bay, should be kept within the sum of $60.

I enclose encumbrance certificate authorizing an expenditure to the above amount. Please obtain an account, in triplicate, covering the cost of the stove, and receipts covering the freight charges. These accounts, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. You should state on each copy of the voucher that the expenditure was incurred under authority of E.R. No. 742.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

No doubt you will be surprised to hear from me.

This fall I sent a sample of the creek water, the only water supply for the school, to the Bureau of Analysis. A report came back stating that the water was heavily polluted with colon bacilli. Mr. Priddle sent this report to the Department. The result is that we are to have a well drilled on the school property.

The point is the Indians think that the well is for their use too. They would use this privilege as an alibi to hang around the school premises any time of the night or day as time is no object to an Indian. This state of affairs would not assure the teacher's safety especially when they have been inbibing too freely.

Knowing the Indians as I do the use of the pump by them would not favour the teacher's protection as regards sanitation.

Then too they are very destructive and the pump would not last long if they were let use it.

I would be very grateful to you Mr. McGoogan if you could arrange to have a notice put up that the pump is for the school only.

Thanking you I remain,

Ottawa, August 16, 1936.

Dear Sir:

Miss Cazaly, teacher of the Goulais Bay Indian Day School, visited the Department today and requested that cupboards be installed - one in the classroom and one in the teacher's living quarters. The cupboard in the classroom is to provide storage facilities for books and classroom equipment, while the cupboard she requires in her living quarters is to provide storage space for her groceries, vegetables, etc.

I would ask that you report regarding the cost of building two inexpensive cupboards which would be adequate to serve the purposes for which they are required. It is considered that if the material was supplied a competent Indian could build the cupboards. I should be pleased to have your report regarding the cost involved in supplying the cupboards.

Miss Cazaly also requested that a small plot of ground be fenced next Spring for garden plots to be conducted by the pupils. I should like to have your views regarding this request, together with an estimate of the cost of the material and labour in fencing a sufficient quantity of ground for gardening purposes. You should also state if you consider that it would be advisable for the pupils to carry on gardening operations at this school next year.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. W. J. GREENING,
SEPARATE SCHOOL INSPECTOR, ON HIS INSPECTION OF
THE GOULAIS BAY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

- Original on No. 13-4-6. -

The school is a very isolated one, so that the teacher has little company but her own. Under these circumstances, the surroundings should be as cheerful as possible. It would be hard to find a school residence much more the reverse. The walls are dark in colour, and the woodwork painted in a very dark gray. The furniture looks as if its one reason for being purchased was its cheapness and unsuitability for anything else. It is cumbrous and cumbersome, dark and ugly.

The work that has always been the rule at this school since I have known it is the more remarkable in view of the living quarters provided.

Because of the financial stringency, I have refrained from bringing the matter to attention before, but would now strongly urge that the kitchen be painted in bright shades, (at least three coats will be necessary), and that a cheap "Breakfast Room" set of modern furniture be provided; the present furniture might be given to some of the Indians on the Reserve (if they will take it) or used for firewood.

A set of furniture as recommended is not very costly. I discussed the matter with Mr. Agent Sims and he would furnish estimates.
Ottawa, January 11, 1937.

EX'D.

Dear Sir:

Inspector Greening's report regarding his inspection of the Goulais Bay Indian Day School has just reached the Department, and he considers that some new furniture should be supplied for the teacher's living quarters. Please let me know the approximate cost of the furniture that you consider necessary.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

The Indian Day School on the Goulais Bay Indian Reserve is badly in need of repairs. The roof is leaking in many places and needs reshingling and the outside of the school needs repainting as the paint is all worn off. The work should be done this coming Summer if at all possible.

The cost of these repairs would be approximately as follows:

**ROOF**
- Shingles, etc. $100.00
- Labour 75.00

**PAINTING**
- Paint 50.00
- Labour 75.00

Total - $300.00

I omitted to put this amount in the estimates for this year as I did not at that time realize the school needed these repairs so badly.

Ottawa,
January 26, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant with reference to repairs required at the Goulais Bay Indian Day School.

Our appropriation for the fiscal year 1942-43 has not yet been finally approved and consequently I am unable to state definitely what amount will be available for repairs at this school. However, I am inclined to feel that we will at least be able to handle the repairs to the roof. Early in May you should forward a requisition for the quantity of shingles and other material required in order that purchase may be made through our Purchasing Branch. At that time you should state if Indian labour is available.

The matter of painting the exterior of the school will receive further consideration when you write again.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

In accordance with your letter of January 26, 1942, 13-4-5, I am forwarding herewith a Requisition for material required to reshingle the roof and paint the exterior of the Goulais Bay Indian Day School.

Indian labour is not available for this work on the Goulais Bay Reserve. At this time of the year most of the Indians are away fishing and only a few of the older men are left, who cannot be depended on to do this class of work.

Mr. Kenneth MacDonald of Goulais Bay has in the past done any repair work that was necessary on this school and I would recommend that he be given this work to do, as he is very dependable and a good workman.

Yours very truly,

R.P.G. Laurence

May 28, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, 13-4-5, with reference to reshingling the roof and painting the exterior of the Goulais Bay Mission Indian Day School.

The colour of paint required is white, with dark green for trimmings. The quotation for paint was obtained from Greenwood Electric & Hardware, Sault Ste. Marie, and that on shingles from Beaver Lumber Co. Ltd., Sault Ste. Marie.

Since my last visit to this school, the plaster on the ceiling of the kitchen has fallen down. The remainder of the plaster should be removed from the ceiling and plaster board substituted. It would require 160 sq. ft. of Plaster Board, three strips 1" x 2" x 12', and 60 ft. of Moulding to do this job. The cost of this extra material would be $8.00. In addition, the Siding on the walls should all be re-nailed as most of it has sprung.

Mr. McDonald states that to reshingle the roof, repair the kitchen ceiling, repaint the school, and renaill the Siding would take him 24 days, @ $6.00 per day.

In my last letter I omitted shingle nails and flashing for the roof. This material would cost as follows:

September 26, 1843.

Mr. R.P.G. Lawrence,
Sault Ste Marie, Ont.

Dear Sir,

As it is quite a distance to the lake from the school, and the children have to pass through a field that is a perfect swamp every spring and fall, in order to get the necessary water needed at the school, I thought it advisable to write and ask if you could make arrangements to have a well at the school.

I believe that if a point was driven into the ground a water level could easily be reached here.

Yours truly,

S. A. Grey
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Attached herewith please find letter received from Miss Fex, School teacher at the Indian Day School, Goulais Bay Reserve requesting a well at the School.

As it is a long way to carry water to this school I recommend that if possible her request be granted.

The approximate cost of same would be $75.00 for material and labour, material $40.00 and labour $35.00.

Kindly advise me regarding this matter.

R. P. J. Laurence.
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

Indian Affairs Branch.

Re: Requisition of 30/7/45 for material for repairing Goulais Bay Indian Day School.

The following additional information is necessary to enable this office to place a purchase order for the building material required:

(a) Are prices obtained by the Indian Agent f.o.b. Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., or f.o.b. school?

(b) The shipping address indicated on requisition is inadequate as Kirby is not a rail point.

SIR:

Your letter has requested that you authorize me to obtain a quantity of suitable furniture to fit up the two living rooms at Eskimo Bay School for use of teachers who are expected to commence duty in about six months. The furniture will be required for living and bed rooms including a small kitchen stove which I think can be obtained from local stores. The other furniture I shall be able to purchase.

The cost of furniture required is estimated at $65.00.

Thank you for your prompt attention.

The teacher's quarters here are not fit for anyone to live in, though your humble servant has done so for 2 winters - was free from rheumatism and neuralgia when first took up my quarters here, now, I am a victim of both (a living barometer) did not affect me any till this last 5 or 6 months. It was a common thing to find the bed covering around where I breathed all night to be stiffened up in the morning with frost almost icicles. I fear my eyes shall, later on, feel the effects of it, as there were mornings I could scarcely open them they were so frozen together. Ottawa is like California compared with this country. Sincerely hope the Department will have the building fitted up more comfortably before another sets in as no one can live in it as it is. At the end of March, 1913, & made known to the Department the condition of the building thinking they would fit it up at once but they payed no attention whatever.
MEMORANDUM.

Miss Kehoe, teacher of the Goulais Bay School, states that some repairs are necessary to the teacher's residence. Mr. Agent McNabb recommends that these should be made.
Ottawa, May 7, 1914.

Sir,

With reference to your verbal statement that the Goulais Bay School building is in need of repairs I have to ask you to be good enough to give a detailed statement of the repairs necessary to make this building comfortable for the winter, together with an approximate estimate of the probable cost. You should also state how you would propose to have the work done. Kindly forward this information as soon as possible so that the work may be undertaken during the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
In reply to your letters of May 7th and June 4th, No 240777/5, in reference to repairs to Goulais Bay School I beg to say that I am enclosing a list of the repairs required. I cannot give you the faintest idea of what those would cost, but I know that the repairs are necessary, as I have mentioned on the list, I would suggest that a practical man be taken from here to give us an estimate. I am sorry for the delay but I only returned from Goulais and Batchewana on Thursday, and have been very busy since. Awaiting your further instructions.

I have the honor to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

J. D. McLean Esq.,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,

Dear Sir,

The interior of this school needs a general cleaning. The walls are in a very smoky dark condition.

I should think a good whitewash would be most sanitary. The paper on the kitchen has to be removed.

The cause of so much smoke escaping is, I think, due to the two openings in the floor being opposite each other at times we were obliged to stop work, for we were blind with the smoke. There should be a new floor or an opening made in the old one.

May I ask you for a woodshed and a new closet for teacher's use?

I should prefer the closet to be built behind the woodshed and a door in the woodshed to lead to the closet. The closets for the use of the school-children are not well screened and are too far from the school.

Agnes Kelly, Teacher at the Coulais Bay school, in reference to repairs to School and Grounds.

This School being so far from the Sault and being so very difficult to get there it is almost impossible for me to get a close estimate of the cost of the repairs required.

Ottawa, Oct. 3, 1922.

Sir:

I have to refer you to official letter of the 15th instant, in which you were requested to purchase certain articles for the use of the teacher's residence at the Goulais Bay Indian Day School. Will you kindly state whether these have yet been supplied by you or not.

Mr. J. M. Bennett, Separate School Inspector, states that the locks on the doors of the school and residence need repairing also that the wood shed leaks and destroys the value of the wood for fuel. He states that most of the hardwood is outside and that there is absolutely no kindling wood. He says further that the front door steps of the school have fallen away and are unsafe and that the foundation of the school on one side needs attention.

I have to request that, besides purchasing the articles which you were authorized in the above mentioned letter, you will arrange to have the repairs made to the locks and the wood shed repaired in order to prevent leakage. You may arrange with an Indian to have the wood split to the proper stove size and have it stored in the wood shed. You should also arrange for the purchase and delivery of the quantity of kindling wood necessary and have it stored with the other wood. Will you also have the steps at the front of the school repaired and the foundation on one side properly banked. The Inspector states it is urgent that the above repairs be carried out and that the articles asked for by the teacher be supplied as soon as possible.

The Inspector further states that a cupboard is needed in the classroom in order to preserve the equipment and books. You should, if possible, arrange with a competent man to build a suitable cupboard in one corner of the room and have it fitted with a lock.

We are anxious to have this school and teacher's residence made as comfortable as possible before the cold weather sets in, and I have to request that you will give all the above repairs your immediate attention and also purchase and have delivered the articles which you were authorized to supply. No undue expenditure should be incurred. You will please have properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, forwarded, covering all the above purchases and repairs.

The Inspector states that the teacher is capable and earnest and that the attendance is good.

I shall be pleased to hear from you at an early date as to the action taken regarding the above.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ont.

Kindly note the contents of the enclosed
Toulais Bay School report. I wrote it as I saw things
there. The teacher arrived to find the living quarters
in a most forbidding condition. The mattress on the bed
was not at all suitable. There wasn't a towel, or bed sheets,
or pillow cases. Cooking utensils rusty and some
useless. I feel that an Indian agent should at
least investigate & prepare for the opening school.
Word for the Batterwood school teachers living quarters was
most attractive & dinner etc all clean, neat & in place,
because Miss Peltier had seen it & left it in
responsible hands.

The Toulais Bay school hasn't proper locks. The
report will give you an idea of what is needed to be done.
Miss Peltier told me she would have returned to
Batterwood if there was a boat when she saw its conditions.
I don't blame her. However I feel that she can see that
this place is put in proper shape if the Department will
As what it is done.

There is no suitable wood for the kitchen stove. There is only 1/2 cord of dry hardwood for the box stove.

I trust that you will look into the matter of making necessary repairs and in making the living quarters of the teacher habitable, comfortable and attractive. This is a place difficult to reach or return from and the pupil attend well. The teacher deserves good living conditions.

In conclusion I would like to know whether or not you wish me to visit this school twice or once a year or whether only once in two years as I have done. Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Goulais Bay Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the condition of the school building and teacher's living quarters. It would appear that Miss Theror left the school and living quarters and furnishings of same in a very unsatisfactory condition, and that certain repairs and furnishings are urgently required. He recommends that the following be supplied for the use of the teacher's living quarters:

- 1 New Mattress,
- 1 Bed Spring,
- 1 Can Enamel for Bed,
- 4 Sheets,
- 2 Pillow Cases,
- Towelling,
- 1 Bed Spread,
- Oilcloth for Bedrooms (8'x10', 10'x11'),
- 11 Yds. Table Oilcloth, 48" wide,

- Clothes Line,
- Water Pail,
- Teapot,

- Potato Pot,
- Double Boiler,
- Bread Pan,
- Sauce Pans.

The chimney also requires to be cleaned. There was no kindling wood and no wood small or short enough to use in the kitchen stove. The kitchen stove is in a dilapidated condition and a new stove is required.

I have to request that you will arrange to have the supplies mentioned above purchased and forwarded to the teacher. Competitive prices should if possible be obtained. While serviceable articles should be purchased it is not intended that any expensive supplies be furnished. A good quality of oilcloth should be supplied. If considered necessary, you may purchase a stove for the kitchen. You should also arrange to have the chimney cleaned.

It would appear that certain supplies which were furnished for the use of the teacher's living quarters in the fall of 1922 have disappeared. It is considered that Miss Theror was very remiss in her duties by not seeing that the furnishings were in proper order, the living quarters in a cleanly condition and the building securely fastened and the key placed in the hands of a reliable person.

SIR,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 15th Instant No. 13-4-8 in reference to supplies to the Coulaie Bay School and in reply have to say that I am very much surprised at some of the articles wanted such as Mattress, Spring and Stove, nearly every Teacher we have had there got a new outfit, we had one teacher wanted a Coal Oil Stove the next one wanted a Range and now another Stove, I cannot get to Coulaie for a week at the least and will investigate those requirements. Tomorrow I have a meeting in reference to the Indian Strip, Saturday is a poor day to go, on Monday I have election for Chief and 2 councilmen on Tuesday and Wednesday is our Fall Fair, on Thursday I am submitting the Surrender for the Strip so that it will be the week after next before I get up there.

I had the School Banked and the Steps fixed last year, I do not agree with the Inspector that the building is in a dilapidated condition or it must have deteriorated very much since July last. I believe in having the Teachers comfortable but some of them are very unreasonable and very hard to please, however I will get everything repaired.

In the matter of a Stove I may say that there are so many residents of this City putting in Gas Stoves that I can buy a nearly new stove only used a month or so much cheaper than a new one. Kindly give me your views on this matter. I will postpone my Holidays again until I get the Schools in shape.

I have the honor to be Sir,

Special Notice:
Mr. Mahon has done business with your Dept for 20 years. Couldn't you send an order direct to him for the mattress and the following articles for immediate delivery to Goulais (Day Mission). At least send the order for the mattress. It's no use waiting for Mr. Mahon and I have gone to the trouble to get this information for you. Besides, wouldn't want a daughter of mine under the circumstances of men around about.

1. Mattress - a gute felt at $2.00 or a white felt @ $3.50. Make your choice. Mr. Jeannelle the Boy's Fisherman at Goulais will see that it is immediately delivered for $2.25.

2. V23yd. velveteen @ $.65 a yard will cover the kitchen and Bedroom floor. But before it is laid down felt carpet paper must be put down - this will be at least 10¢ a yard. If you don't do this then hardwood floor should be put in.

3. A teacher chair will cost $1.90. She needs a chair to sit on surely.

4. That old Heat Picture mentioned can be sent to Mr. Mahon & he will frame it for $2.00.
Notes on Goulais Bay.

Please note my report well.

1. More desks (5) as needed. They need not be new; old ones from the O.S. school could be used or new ones obtained.

2. Mattress is urgently needed—wooden blocks for kitchen & bedroom 3 ft wide and material (cheats) for the windows & curtains, 10 yds would do it.

3. The floor 11' x 11' + 8' x 10' need oilcloth to cover them but it must not be placed under a heavy thickness of packing pipe be sent with it for undercoat. The floor would only cut it to pieces.

Maybe you could afford to put a hardwood floor in these rooms? Possibly should be done.

4. A carpenter & wheelbarrow needed.

5. Teacher's desk chair is absolutely devoid of any back and must have gone out the when the pioneer firm entered. One is needed.

6. Quickly send all supplies. Also textbooks as soon as possible without waiting for teacher's signature.

7. Send along a register.

8. Don't forget the kitchen supplies needed.

Although I have marked George Cowie's conduct C, it is improving. He is in no way immoral, only at a self-assertive stage. I believe this quality is finding its groove. Sir,

With reference to the Hiawatha School

I beg to say that the Secretary of the Trustees Board has notified me that the Department is some $25 short in the grant of $380.00 per year for the year 1923.

We are getting excellent service through this school, the board is paying a salary of $600.00 now and, as white two thirds are Indian children, in attendance I would recommend that the balance be paid.

The Secretary

Ottawa, January 12, 1924.

Sir,-

In reply to your letter of the 7th instant, I beg to say that, as you are aware, the Department allows the Hiawatha School an annual grant of $300.00. Previously the Department paid this grant in four instalments of $75.00, each, at the end of each quarter.

There are ten teaching months in the school year and we consider the academic year to begin September 1st and end June 30th.

Commencing September 1, 1923, the Department is paying all day schools on the ten months basis and, therefore, the Hiawatha school was paid $30.00 at the end of September and will be paid $90.00 at the end of each of the other three quarters in the school year. In other words for the school year 1923-24, they will receive $300.00, which is the same amount as has been allowed them previously.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

R. J. McCamus, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Keene, Ont.

I have been approached by Mr. Godfrey, Secretary Treasurer of the Otonabee S. S. # 11 school, concerning the grant to this school in consideration of the teachers salary in connection with the Rice Lake Reserve.

It appears that the quarterly cheque has not been received to the amount of $120.00. Mr. Godfrey asked me to make this inquiry and as I have had nothing to do with this school in this connection, I am putting forward this inquiry at Mr. Godfrey's request.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, March 8th, 1926.

Sir,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the payment of the grant for the Hiawatha School.

The last return received from this school was for the quarter ended June 30th last and was forwarded under cover of your letter of that date. For some years past, the Department has been allowing this school a grant at the rate of $300. a year, but payment is only made on receipt of a return showing the names of the Indian children in attendance. Please have the Secretary of the School Board prepare and forward, on the usual forms provided for that purpose, returns for the quarters ended September 30th and December 31st, 1927. These should be forwarded through your office and, on receipt of them, payment of the usual grant will be made.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

V. Mac. Eastwood, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Peterborough, Ont.

Mr Agent McFarlane forwards a resolution from the Rice Lake Band in which they ask to be allowed to erect a new building two stories high, 28 by 40 feet, for a combined school and council house. The Agent states that although the existing building is old it could be put in repair at a small cost and that their present council house is a good building, two stories high, 30 by 25 feet, the ground floor of which is rented to School Section No. 11 of the township of Otomabee.

The Rice Lake Indian school was lately closed and the children are attending the white school held in the council house, and when a definite arrangement is made with the Public School Trustees there will be no need to re-open the Indianschool.

The capital of this band amounts to only $21,000 and I do not think that there is any need to spend any of it for the above purpose. It would appear to me that it more a matter of rivalry between the Mud and Rice Lake bands than any practical benefit it would be to the Indians.

On No. 1 of this file Mr Agent McFarlane writes under date of the 3rd instant that the Trustees of School Section No. 11 wish the Department to contribute $100 a year towards the salary of their teacher in lieu of a per capita grant of 25 cents a month for every Indian pupil in attendance.
The Hiawatha, or Rice Lake school, was one of those taken over by the Department from the Methodist Missionary Society last July and closed in consequence of the arrangement made with the white school, and I think it would be better to accede to the Trustees' demand and contribute $100 annually towards their teacher's salary, than to re-open their school.

There are fifteen Indian and eleven white children on the roll. The size of school room is 24 by 20 by 10 = 4800 cubic feet, number of pupils it should accommodate 4800 ÷ 250 = 19. Dear Sir:

I have before me two communications from the Dept. in regard to my report on the Hiawatha School. They bear No. 154237-6 and dates June 13th and July 6th.

In connection with the question of a grant to the school, permit me to call attention to a few facts.

1. The grant from the Dept. of Indian Affairs was increased a few years ago from $150 to $300. In regard to that increase I was not consulted and do not know by what influence it was secured, but I do know that it was never merited. It was chiefly in consideration of that increase that I have been urging that the trustees should do something in return in the way of improved accommodation.

2. As you are probably aware, the school, like every other public school derives a revenue of $300 from the township, a part of which is contributed by that section as this is raised by a uniform levy over the whole township. Other schools have to supplement this by, at least, as much more, but this school, owing to the generosity of the Dept. of Indian Affairs, has had to levy no section tax since the "Indian Grant" was increased.

3. Until the present year, when the provincial grant was
increased owing to a change in the basis of distribution, it has been quite small compared with the grant from your department. This year it will amount to about $160. You will therefore see that up till now, at least, the withholding of this grant would not have had any great influence on the section.

4. Then there is another consideration. Were this school for the white children of the section only, I should not be disposed to make much objection to the accommodations. But what do the trustees get the special "Indian Grant" for? Is it simply to purchase the privilege of sitting in the school and sharing in the instruction given the other children? I would suppose that when they are given a grant as large as is being paid this school, they would be expected to furnish something extra in the way of accommodation or instruction for the Indian children.

In my opinion, they ought to be made to understand definitely that unless they do something the grant will be cut down to say what it formerly was. If kept posted as to what is being done, I am perfectly willing to co-operate with the Department in any effort that may be made to bring pressure on the trustees to induce them to do what is right. I am of opinion that there is little fear of their severing their connection with the Dept. if they are dealt with reasonably.

I have the honour to be Respectfully yours,

Richard Lee.

Sir,

In reply to official letter of the Department No. 264235-5 dated the 3rd of November and also of a later date. Regarding the complaint of Mr. Inspector Lee that the Shiweta school was out of repair and an unqualified teacher employed I beg to say that the school house needs painting on the outside and the out buildings are in need of some slight repairs otherwise the building as it stands is in fairly good repair. The trustees engaged a man to do the work this last spring but he disappointed them. They fully intend having it done next spring. The school is warm and comfortable and quite large enough for the number of scholars in the section.

I must say Mr. Lee is a hard man to understand. In 1876 he complained about the school being too small, not air space enough. I submitted a plan to enlarge namely to cut an opening in the south end 16' wide to build and addition 16'x14' taken down the clock records and put them in the south end of the new part and also move the stove into the new part. The Department approved of this and did act.
Sir,

The trustees but Mr. Lee would have none of it; he wanted the school enlarged and all the windows placed in the south. Again in 1918 after a good deal of persuasion I succeeded in getting the trustees to agree to this plan, which was to take off the roof, take out the west-side and add 16'x20' put on a cottage roof have the entrance in the east with all the windows in the south. We arranged a meeting at the school hall. Mr. Lee down showed him our plans but Mr. Lee said the school house was large enough, all he suspected at that time was that it be painted and a new system of ventilation put in. I explained to him the present system and in a few days after he wrote the trustees to say that the system of ventilation was all right that he had not understood it.

As for the other part of Mr. Lee's complaint the employing of an unqualified teacher, it must be borne in mind that it is not always an easy matter to procure a qualified teacher for the Hiawatha school owing to there being Indian children in attendance even were there an abundance of them, the great majority of teachers now available are young girls, and they shy off from an
Sir,

Indian school. Certainly all the teachers we have had have enjoyed the work very much after they got to know the people.

The trustees always advertised and last midsummer they received two applications which they accepted in turn but the applicants took other schools.

Miss Kylie our present teacher is teaching on a permit but I have no hesitation in saying that she is doing the best work of any teacher we have had since the late Miss Throop resigned in 1916. Miss Throop taught the school for several years and she was acknowledged to be one of the very best teachers in the county. Miss Kylie's manner and methods are very much like Miss Throop's. She is quite capable and her discipline I might say is perfect. Every child of school age on the reserve is in attendance and the parents well satisfied with her progress.

In reply to your memorandum of November 30th, 1950, files 398-1 and 398-9, I wish to inform you that the site on which the Hiawatha School is situated was patented to the Trustees of School District No. 11, Township of Otenabec.

November 29, 1950.

CHIEF, EDUCATION DIVISION

Hiawatha Provincial Day School

With the recently appointed Superintendent at Peterborough, Mr. E.A. Adams, I visited this school on Tuesday, November 28.

As photographs later will show it is a small old-type building with windows on both sides. It is heated by a stove. Surprisingly it is well lighted electrically and has toilets of the type which we are putting into our latest schools. The desks are very much the worse for wear and tear and there are not enough of them. There is a piano but no radio or phonograph or electric visual aid apparatus.

The present teacher is Mr. Fred Plato. He has an Interim First Class Certificate and this is his first appointment. His salary is $1,900.

The school is under the management of the school board for Otonabee Township, the secretary being Mrs. Ralph Godfrey, R.R. No. 2, Keene, Ontario.

The Ontario School Inspector is Mr. K.O. Birkin, M.A., B. Paed., Court House, Peterborough, Ontario.

This school is the only one which is not included in the larger area for administrative and taxation purposes, although it is visited by the Manual Training instructor, Mr. McCall, on Tuesday afternoons between recess and dismissal.
The Branch has been paying a fixed sum per annum in respect of the Indian pupils but the sum is not adjusted on the basis of attendance as is done elsewhere. There is also some doubt as to what the school board should provide to the pupils. In the matter of text books, etc., the teacher reports that pupils have had to buy their own although the Ontario Department of Education has a system for providing these at the public expense. The Chief, however, suggests that any increase in the grant made by our Department would be attended by a reduction in "the grant from Toronto".

It seems appropriate that we should now attempt to improve the educational facilities provided for the Indian children at this school and I have drafted letters to initiate investigation.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Ottawa, December 11, 1928.

Sir:

With further reference to my letter of the 26th ultimo, concerning the school at Honey Harbour, I have now to inform you that the Rev. Father Collins of Parry Sound and Mr. Indian Agent Daly visited the Department today. The Department has decided to allow a grant of $550.00 per academic year towards the current expenses of conducting this school. Will you please inform me to whom our grant should be paid and indicate to the official trustee that our cheques will go forward once every quarter, if returns showing the attendance and the days taught, are forwarded to Mr. Indian Agent Daly. This grant will be allowed from the first of the current academic year. The school will be recognized by this Department as a combined separate and Indian day school. I regret that the Department cannot assist in the matter of capital expenditure. I may add that we have promised to honour requisitions for texts, scribblers and similar classroom supplies.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN,
Aust. Deputy & Secretary.

J. H. Bennett, Esq., M. A.,
Inspector of Separate Schools,
47 Browning Ave.,
Toronto 6, Ont.

The Secretary,
Department Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir;

Enclosed please find Quarterly report from Honey Harbour Combined School at Honey Harbour Muskoka District. I have to state that I have not visited this school this year. I intended doing so on my proposed trip to Moose Point, but as I was able to send the supplies down to Moose Point with the Chief, I did not make the trip, but intend to make a trip to Moose Deer Point sometime between the 12th and 17th of October, so that I will be able to get the schools settled down after the teachers have attended the Convention.

I will also make a trip when at Moose Point to Honey Harbour, which is about 25 miles farther down the lake.

The reports from the Rev. Black, who is secretary of this combined school, have been very satisfactory, and Johnson the teacher has been retained for the present term because of his satisfactory service there. I will report later as to conditions at the school at Honey Harbour when I make my trip.

Trusting this will be satisfactory.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Agent.

JMD/EK.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, June 23rd, 1949.

W.A. Robinson, Esq.,
Midland, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Robinson:

I am in receipt of your letter of June 15th with reference to the school at Honey Harbour, Ontario.

We have allowed a grant to this school for several years past on the understanding that there were a number of Indian children attending it.

Recently the Indian Superintendent forwarded to us a list of the children attending this school. On reviewing it our officials found that none of the children mentioned on the list had Indian status. As a result, we wrote Reverend Father J.S. Collins on May 5th, advising him that the children reputed to be Indians were not recognized as such by the Department. No reply has yet been received to that letter.

Sincerely yours,

PP/ST Director.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Kaboni Indian Day School, states that there are at least 17 children of school age at Wikwemikongsing who are too far away to attend. He recommends that a bus service be arranged for after the summer holidays to take these children to and from their homes, which would be cheaper than re-opening the Wikwemikongsing school.

I shall be pleased if you will make enquiry regarding the situation mentioned by the Inspector. You should state the number of children of school age at Wikwemikongsing who do not attend school, and you should give your views regarding the suggestion of the Inspector that arrangements be made for a bus service to draw these children to the Kaboni school. You should also state whether it would be possible to arrange with an Indian having the necessary team and rig for the purpose, and the cost per month that would be charged for the service. The Inspector is of the opinion that, if a bus service is installed for a period of, say, 6 months in each year, it would not cost more than approximately $40 per month.

You will be good enough to give this matter your consideration, and report your opinion to the Department, in order that, if it is decided to arrange for a bus service, the necessary steps can be taken to begin the work on or about the 1st of October, next, or the 1st of September, if you think it should start from this earlier date. Such an arrangement, if carried out, might be the easiest solution of providing educational facilities for the children residing at Wikwemikongsing.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th instant, regarding the application of Miss Florence Fortin for the position of teacher of the Kaboni Indian Day School, to begin duties after the midsummer holidays.

In reply I beg to say that it is considered, taking into account Miss Fortin's age and qualifications, that her services would hardly prove satisfactory for this school. There is an enrolment of about 27 pupils, and besides, living quarters are provided, where a teacher would have to reside and do her own housekeeping. We are of the opinion that Miss Fortin is too young and has not sufficient experience to be appointed teacher of this school.

You should endeavour to obtain the services of an older teacher having some experience and, if possible, the necessary qualifications. If you are unable to secure such a teacher, it may be possible for us to make an appointment from the applications which we have on file. You may inform Miss Fortin that her application is not accepted and you should let us know, at an early date, whether you have been successful in obtaining any further applications.

Your obedient servant,

Madam:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letters of the 9th and 10th instant, accepting the position as teacher of the Kaboni Indian Day School for the next school year, and requesting particulars regarding the school.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is pleased to accept your services, and, as stated in official letter of the 5th instant, the salary will be at the rate of $750 per annum for the ten teaching months in the year. Besides the salary, you will also receive bonus at the rate of $15 per month up to March 31st, which is the end of the present fiscal year. This is the full period for which Parliament has provided for the payment of bonus, and we have no knowledge as to whether it will be continued after that date or not. You will therefore receive a combined salary and bonus to the amount of $850 per annum, which will be paid at the end of each quarter, on a monthly basis of ten teaching months in the year.

Your duties will commence when the school re-opens after the present summer holidays, on September 2nd next. I am enclosing herewith a quarterly school return form on the back of which you will see the Indian Day School regulations giving full particulars regarding the length of each term, holidays, payment of salary, etc. There are about 35 children of school age, the average attendance last year being 20 pupils.

There is only one teacher employed at this school, and living quarters are provided for her. The teacher does her own housekeeping.

The local Indian Agent is Mr. R. J. Lewis, Manitowaning, Ont., who is being informed of your appointment, and requested to give you every assistance he can in your work at this school.

You can obtain particulars at a C.P.R. ticket office regarding travelling to Little Current. When you arrive at Little Current you can proceed to the school with the mail carrier.

My Dear Kenzie,

I did not finish my scribbling yesterday. The train left earlier than expected. I come to thank once more for your great charity in desiring to yourself me about the teachers.

I am now rejoiced by the hopes of a school in Skegwanish—!!

Concerning Gaboni school, as it is not in my district, I am not able to assist its teachers. For any occasion, I visit the schools every week, and use my utmost energy to stimulate the pupils and facilitate the success of the teachers. Miss Kerr is extremely grateful to you for giving her an opportunity to teach; but as Gaboni school is very isolated and very hard to reach, she would prefer
West Bay or Sheguiandah. For an outside teacher, it does not matter so much if she be a few miles further away from home. Could you not give the Colonie or other school to Miss Levallee? The poor girl is hard up, from working for a low salary, in Sudbury. She has faithfully served the Department by successful teaching, during several years. I would like to see her great wish fulfilled by her obtaining a school.

Her trouble at West Bay was due mainly to the construction of the new class-room. The Indians wrongly blaming her for being the cause of the new building, became sore at her, without notice.

However, I leave the whole affair to your long experienced wisdom, and assure you again of my very affectionate gratitude for your untiring kindness.

Ever more devotedly your obedient servant,

Eug. A. Papineau, P.J.
