Dear sir,

Last Spring, the inspector at his visit here, spoke of the closing of the Gaboni school. I come today to ask you the favour not to do it at least this year. After this visit there were 13 children present at school, this proves that there are enough children to keep it open, but the carelessness of the parents is the cause of the lack of attendance. I promise to remember to the parents the threat, because they are very much afraid of losing this school, what would be a very bad thing. It would be to send these children to the old time of wilderness, as none of them could reach the school of Wikwemikong. Spanish? I cannot place even the children of Spanish River Band Sagamok. Here at Wikwemikong I chosed those who are the farthest, and Spanish will not be able to receive half of them, there is no room for them all.

I may say that the teacher of Gaboni have something to do with that lack of interest; so the one of last year, she may have done her best, but as she was sickly, every thing went the same way, and she one day told one Indian: I do not wonder that the children are not interested in such a state of health as I am. I would ask the Department to take the matter into consideration.
I am told that at Garden River there is good teacher who was teaching at the public school and had to give up the teaching, she wrote to me then last winter, she probably would be glad to have this school of Gaboni.

Shall we have the pleasure to have a school soon at Sagamok Spanish River Band. It is too sad to see such a crowd of children deprived of instruction. I am trying to place some at Spanish, but there is vacancy enough for many. All those I want to place are between 9 and 13 years old. 25 at least are of age to go to school.

I wrote to the Department last winter about this school, and I did not receive any answer, did I speak too hard? If so I apologize, because my intention was to impose, but to place the case before the Department, as I know that he is very anxious to see the Indians educated.

Yours sincerely,

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, regarding the attendance and teaching services at the Kaboni Indian Day School. In reply I have to say that it is not the intention of the Department to close this school for the coming academic year. The Separate School Inspector, who visited this school at the end of May last, reported as follows:

"I consider Miss McGregor a capable and energetic teacher, and although she seems to have worked hard, the pupils do not appear to have made any considerable progress. This is partly the result of irregular attendance. I cannot convince myself that much interest is taken in the school by either the pupils or their parents, nor do the children appear to evince any great desire to master the English language. It is now easily the poorest Indian day school visited by me and this in spite of the efforts of teachers really desirous of producing results. If Kaboni is kept open, Miss McGregor's re-appointment thereto for the coming school year is recommended."

It would appear that the results obtained at this school are due entirely to the indifference of the parents, who do not see that their children attend regularly. The Department will continue this school for the coming academic year, with Miss McGregor as teacher, and, if the results show that the parents do not take more interest and do not encourage a regular attendance, the question of closing the school at the end of the next academic year will have to receive serious consideration.

Mr. Agent Lewis is being written and requested to use every effort to encourage the parents to see that their children attend regularly. It may be necessary to enforce the compulsory clause in the Indian Act to compel a more regular attendance. Judging from the Separate School Inspector's report, Miss McGregor has done her best in her work but is handicapped by the irregular attendance of the pupils. I shall be pleased if you will continue to use your good influence with the parents and encourage them in every way possible to send their children to school regularly.

You will be written in a separate communication with reference to the school at Sagamook.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Reverend C. Belanger, S. J.,
Wikwemikong, Ont.

Sir:

The Department has received a communication from the Reverend Father Belanger, Wikwemikong, regarding the Kaboni Indian Day School. The Inspector states that neither the pupils nor the parents take much interest in the school. He has recommended, if this school is kept open, that Miss McGregor be re-appointed.

The Department desires to continue the work at Kaboni and the re-appointment of Miss McGregor for the coming school year is approved. It will be necessary, however, to take some action in forcing the parents to see that their children attend more regularly. When this school re-opens after the holidays, the Department will expect you to see the parents and inform them that they are to send their children to school regularly. If not, it will be necessary to take action under Section 10 of the Regulations.

The Department will expect to have a report from you, regarding the attendance, at the end of September, next, stating the action taken by yourself in maintaining the same among the children. D. MacKenzie,

Agent Lewis has notified me yesterday that the Dept. had accepted my resignation, I am very thankful because the Dr. advises me to take a complete rest for a whole year, so I have decided to go home to my parents in the states.

Now Mr. MacKenzie I haven't the money to take me there so I want to ask you if the Dept. would not send me my check or part of it enough to take me home, it will be very hard if I have to stay here till January for that money. I thought perhaps that in a case like this the Dept. would not be so hard.

I have asked Mr. Lewis and he told me that we could not get any money before our reports were in. I decided to write you and I know you will understand and I feel assured you will do all you can for me. Am very sorry not to be able to finish the term and to put you to all this inconvenience, assure you it is very hard for me, but I am unable to do otherwise.

Madam:

Pursuant to your visit to the Department yesterday, I have to confirm your appointment as teacher of the Kaboni Indian Day School, at a salary of $75 a teaching month, less 10% percent - duties to commence on September 5th.

It will be necessary for you to provide your own food and it would be advisable to take a little linen and any other personal effects that you would like to have with you.

The Department also allows the teacher of this school $50 a year, less 10 percent, for janitor services. You can make whatever arrangements you wish regarding this work.

Mr. R. J. Lewis, Manitowaning, Ont., is Indian Agent, and you should look to him for advice and assistance in all matters pertaining to the conduct of the school. He will supply you with requisition forms and quarterly return forms.

During each academic year the school will be inspected twice by a provincial separate school inspector, who will advise you concerning teaching methods.

Please advise me as soon as possible of your acceptance of this position.

Sir:

I have the honor to enclose herewith a Resolution passed by the Chief and Council of the Manitoulin Island Unceded reserve, also a document signed by a number of the Indians requesting the Department of Indians Affairs to erect a Day School in the Kaboni settlement.

I would most respectfully recommend that the question of erecting a new school and teachers residence in this settlement be given some consideration as it is one of the best farming sections on the reserve and there are some 30 children of school age, also 17 under school age within 2 miles of the proposed site, so that there would be sufficient pupils to have a good attendance. There are now 13 from this section attending the Industrial School at Spanish, and the parents would rather have them at home if there was a school for them to attend, as they are all progressive farmers and able to support their children.

Improved land suitable for a school site can be secured from John Kaboni at a reasonable price, also enough ground for a garden in order that the children may be taught gardening, which the Department is desirous of.

If the Department decides granting those Indians their request, I would most respectfully recommend that it be ready for September quarter.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,

In regard to the Kabani School, I thank you very kindly for drawing my attention to the matter as I only had the plans & specifications for a few hours as when I went to see them again they were on the Indian side so I did not see them again until today.

I have looked the connecting of the cellar floor the 3 closets & the Black Boards this would amount to about £230 or two hundred & thirty dollars it does not state in the specifications for the contractor to put in seats or to furnish the Bell if those were to be put in it would be the cost of those extra. I have had some experience in building school houses as I have built most of the schools around here in the last few years again thanking you & looking for an early reply & am yours

Very Truly,

Neil McMartin
Oct 19th 1915

Dear Sir,

Since writing you a few days ago I have been over the ground located for the Harbour School & Dwelling & have changed the location I find the new site much harder to drain also to level. I also find that stone & gravel will have to be drawn a long distance as I was told that it could be got near by along with this & the bad roads caused by the fall rains & other details I am compelled to ask an increase of $930.00 over my tender of $2835.00 making a total of $3765.00 three thousand seven hundred & sixty-five.

I am Yours Very Truly,

Neil McMartin
MEMORANDUM:

Mr. D. C. Scott -

With reference to the memoranda from your Department regarding tenders for the teacher's residence at Kaboni Settlement, on Manitoulin Island, the Minister has decided that the latest tender of Mr. McMartin shall be accepted, as it is the lowest, but that the work of construction shall not be begun until spring.
Ottawa, October 27, 1915.

His Royal Highness
the Governor General in Council.

The undersigned has the honour to report that, a combined school house and teacher's residence being required at Kahoni settlement, on Manitoulin Island, tenders were called for and the following were received:

R. Hawes, Sudbury, Ont., $6850.00
Wm. Fryer, Collingwood, Ont., 5050.00
Woolrich & Thornton, Sault Ste Marie, Ont., 4077.00
Neil McMartin, Manitowaning, Ont., 3765.00

R. Hawes' tender was not accompanied by security cheque for 10% of the amount of his tender, as required by the Department's advertisement.

The undersigned would recommend, pursuant to the requirements of subsection 2 of section 36 of the Public Works Act, that the contract for the work be awarded to Mr. Neil McMartin for the amount of his tender as above cited, namely, $3765.00, and that, under section 90 of the Indian Act, authority be given for charging the same to the capital at the credit of the Indians of Manitoulin Island unceded, which amounts to $71,628.51.

Mr. McMartin's tender is considered fair and reasonable, the Department's estimate for the building being $4500. It is to be understood that the work of construction shall not be begun until next spring.

Sir:

I am in receipt of Official Letter No. 464780 of the 9th Instant, with regard to Mr. Inspector Finn reporting to the Department that the Kaboni school building is not completed as the dividing wall in the cellar between excavated and unexcavated portion has not been erected, and in reply I have the honor to report that when this building was under the course of erection I visited it quite often and had a careful oversight of the work, and by the plans and specifications I could not see that it called for a centre wall through the cellar under the school part, the dividing wall between the school and the residential portion, and the centre wall dividing the cellar under the residential portion were erected in accordance with the plans.

The centre beam under the school rests on two big cement piers, which take the place of a wall and is much better on account of the light. There are two windows in the unexcavated portion which show light across into the furnace room, and by having a centre wall the furnace room would be almost in total darkness as there is only one small window in that portion. If a centre wall was to be erected it would hardly be reasonable to have two windows in the unexcavated portion, where light is not required, and only one small window in the furnace portion.

I might say that occasionally a little earth falls down on the basement floor, but nothing to hurt anything, and it is much better to leave the cellar as it is than to erect a centre wall and shut out the light.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

I am in receipt of Official Letter No. 464780-5 of the 11th Instant, with regard to some water being in the basement of the Kaboni Day School, and in reply I have the honor to report that there was a little water in one portion of the basement under the residential part of this building on account of the heavy rains early in the season. The troughs carried the water from the roof to one corner of the building, and such an amount of water falling in the one place caused a hole to be worn in the ground near the basement which held the water and soaked through into the cellar.

In order to prevent this it will be necessary to dig a small drain to carry the water away from the pipe which leads to the trough.

This building is situated on very high ground and has good drainage, and the only possible way of any dampness being in the basement is from the water falling from the roof and soaking through at the corner.

Extract from teacher's Annual Report on the Kaboni Indian School for the year ended March 31, 1920. Original on 160370-26F. Ont.

Building.-

Doors and windows are in need of repair and to prevent water running into the cellar it will be necessary to bank up with clay all around.

No woodshed and one is badly needed.

Remarks.-

Although this school is new and of a fine appearance there are some things not at all in good condition. The belfrey has never been properly finished and every time that we have rain we are obliged to place pans to catch the water. On the north side the house is settling and this prevents the doors from closing properly. The locks have been broken for over a year or longer.

There are so many mud holes that it would be necessary to cart about 10 loads of gravel to fill them up. Children have no place to play without getting their feet wet.

Rose Fagan,

Teacher.
Ottawa, April 6, 1920.

Sir,

The teacher of the Kaboni Indian Day School, in her report for the year ended March 31st, last, states that the doors and windows of the school building are in need of repair and that, in order to prevent water running into the cellar, it will be necessary to bank up with clay all round the building. She also states that the belfry has never been properly finished and every time it rains she is obliged to place pans to catch the water. She states also that the house is settling and this prevents the doors from closing properly, and that the locks have been broken for over a year or longer.

She also requests that a woodshed be built and states that it is badly needed.

She states that the grounds are full of mud holes and that it will be necessary to cart ten loads of gravel to fill them up, and that the children have no place to play without getting their feet wet.

I have to request that you will be good enough to furnish a report concerning all the above matters and what you would recommend should be done. The cost of the work should be stated in each case. You should furnish a report as soon as possible, as it is considered that, if the conditions to the building are as stated, the necessary repairs should be made.

Your obedient servant,

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

With regard to the belbry I consider that $5.00 will cover the repairs required to prevent it from leaking, and the ground where the children play is unlevel and sticky when it rains. I estimate that it will take 50 loads of gravel which will cost $25.00 to put it in shape.

There should be plenty of room in the basement under the class-room and residence for wood if the space is not used as a store-room for tables, barrels, etc; therefore, I cannot recommend that a woodshed should be built.

The Church Bell and Its Mission

In the days of King Solomon, the Jewish nation, then at the zenith of its power, was summoned to the worship of Jehovah by the blast of silver trumpets from the inner courts of the most magnificent temple ever erected by the hand of man. The forefathers of these worshippers throughout their eventful history had been summoned to battle by similar stirring peals, and all through the history of mankind we find that for the prompt assembling of scattered masses of men at a given point some sonorous, far-reaching sound has been employed. The trumpet that in various forms served well its purpose in the days of yore has bowed to the inevitable march of civilization, and for many generations the universal summoner has been the powerful yet pleasing voicings of large bells of various types.

It is impossible to justly estimate the actual importance of an acceptable church bell or to appreciate its powers to impress and influence the community upon whose ears its pleadings fall at the stated hours for worship. To the failure to realize its powers of building up and drawing together a congregation, rather than to indifference or parsimony, may be ascribed the absence of a bell from many a sacred edifice where its beneficent powers would quickly be apparent. A live church is of necessity one that asserts itself in a community and constantly keeps before those it seeks to attract, its sacred mission and work. This cannot be more effectually accomplished than by means of a sweet-toned, sonorous, far-reaching voice, with its inestimable powers to remind, invite and recall to a sense of duty the scattered elements of a rural or a city community. Its voice, lifted above all other sounds at the regular recurring seasons for worship, has a drawing power positively magnetic. A church, feeble by reason of its lack of the one thing needful, viz., numbers, never fails to trace a wonderful gain to the erection of a really fine bell, with its hearty summons "to thee, and thy son and to thy daughter, and to thy stranger that is within thy gates." There is in every community an element of indifference on the subject of church-going manifested by a class who offer for their failures to attend the regular means of grace such excuses as: "Did n't know where your church was or when service began," "Did not know there was a church so near by," etc. From this class a lively, pleasing bell entirely removes such pretexts, and in the case of the merely indifferent it constantly wins many an attendant that, without its invitation, would not have entered His courts. All the members of any community have a vital interest in a church bell to herald the various events constantly transpiring in their midst. For the merry wedding peal, for occasions of general rejoicing or national celebrations, for the solemn funeral...

Concerning Dimensions

We desire to invite especial attention to the all-important features of the size and weight of bells in relation to their tone and sound carrying powers. In the case of all good bells, weight and size mean richness of tone and penetrating power; the larger the bell the more sonorous and pleasant its utterances will be and the further its sound waves will flow. For this reason purchasers should invariably select a large bell, indeed a larger bell than may seem sufficient, and by so doing they will never fail to congratulate themselves upon the satisfactory performance of such an instrument. Mounted as they are there is so little jar or strain incident to the proper ringing of the Blymyer Bell that any ordinary belfry will easily carry our largest sizes. The distance which a bell may be heard depends both on its weight and diameter, and, other features being equal, a bell of a given weight and specified diameter can be heard further than one of equal weight and smaller diameter, and in this respect our bells possess a distinct advantage over all copper and tin bells. The same amount of money will purchase a considerably larger and heavier Blymyer Bell than can be procured of copper and tin, and will consequently secure one vastly superior in volume and quality of tone to such smaller copper and tin bell, at a corresponding cost.
The Blymyer vs. Copper and Tin Bells

IT IS an undisputed fact that in the founding of all copper and tin—that is to say, of all so-called bell-metal bells—results are strictly governed by three things, viz., dimensions, quality of metal used, and distribution of said metal. All makers of such bells are practically confined to the use of an identical pattern, and consequently the difference in performance of their bells depends solely upon the proportions of copper and tin used; the finer the metal the better the bell, and of course an inferior bell means simply bad metal in its make-up. The tone power of a bell and the quality of that tone depend upon the grade of metal used, the amount of such metal and the extent of the available resonant surface, the latter of course being dependent upon dimensions. Other features being equal, from the bell with the largest diameter and consequent greatest resonant surface, the deepest, richest and most far reaching tones will be obtained. In the vitally important feature of resonant surface the Blymyer Bell simply distances all others, as our composition permits of greatly increased diameters for bells of corresponding weights, with the great gain of resonant surface accompanying such increase. Take, by way of illustration, a thousand-pound copper and tin bell and a thousand-pound Blymyer Bell; the diameter of the former will be thirty-six or thirty-seven inches, which dimensions, as already stated, are absolutely arbitrary, and must be rigidly adhered to with the best results in view. The latter, namely, the one thousand-pound Blymyer Bell, has a diameter of forty-four inches in place of thirty-six or thirty-seven inches, and consequently furnishes about twenty per cent more of resonant surface, with a consequent tone and power quite beyond the compass of any copper and tin bell of such weight. This single comparison will be found applicable to our entire range of sizes. To the above easily recognizable mechanical advantages must be added the very important one of greatly reduced cost.

General Information

We want to impress upon intending bell purchasers the advantage of buying a large bell; not that the small chapel or school should have a 1,500 or 2,000-pound bell, but that the bell selected be the largest the tower will contain, or the largest that can be afforded. A bell is an investment of a lifetime and future requirements should be considered. Satisfaction always results from the installation of a large bell, for the size and weight govern tone, volume of sound and carrying power.

Regarding the carrying power, the impression is rather general that bells can be heard in proportion to their weight, that is, a bell of 1,000 pounds should be heard twice as far as one weighing 500 pounds. This is not possible, simply because the larger bell does not possess anything like twice the resonant surface of the smaller one. A bell with a sharp, shrill and penetrating tone is naturally heard farther in proportion to its weight than the large bell with the full and deep tone. Instances of this occurrence often cause unfavorable comment. The larger bells are admired for their great volume, their deep, dignified and sympathetic tones and the altogether sonorous, mellow and church-like sound.

When bells are being tolled or struck while hung stationary, they will not, as a rule, be heard more than one-half as far as when swung. The swinging motion throws the mouth of the bell up at each stroke and the sound is carried off and out as it cannot be from a stationary bell. It also imparts a certain richness to the tone which is entirely lacking in a bell struck while at rest.

The Belfry

The belfry should be as open as possible to give full vent to the sound as exposure to rain or snow will not injure the Blymver Bell. It should be carefully ceiled above the bell and floored directly under it, and it is desirable in square belfries which are partially closed to board up the corner angles from floor to ceiling and from window to window. Belfry windows should be as large as possible and should reach from floor to ceiling, indeed the best results are obtainable from the largest possible belfry and one entirely open and unobstructed.

The belfry floor should be sheathed with tin and kept well painted to protect it from the weather and to exclude rain from the tower below. A good solid floor under the bell and a tight ceiling not more than two or three feet above the mountings are most important features. As a matter of fact the belfry should always be built to suit the bell and not a bell purchased and set up in a close belfry to do itself and its makers seemingly little credit. The bell tower should rise high enough above the highest point of the church roof and when possible above adjacent buildings or trees.

Directions for Raising Bells

In constructing towers, provision should be made for hoisting the bell into position from the inside, but by the use of a simple tackle, bells may readily be taken in from the outside. (See illustration herewith.) Care should be taken that the hoisting apparatus is amply strong; and the work may be done from within, or in the case of very heavy bells the hoisting rope may be carried to the ground and passed through a fixed pulley when any number of men or a team may be employed. After a bell has been raised to the proper height it is readily drawn into the belfry by means of a small rope or tackle. The frame of mountings should first be placed in its proper position and then the bell with its yoke and springs should be lifted to its place with the wheel on the side opposite...
to the tolling hammer. The bell should then be swung mouth up and the clapper inserted, care being taken to drive the key well through and the ends opened up so that it cannot work out. The bell should then be rung to test the adjustment of springs and clapper which may have been deranged in transit or in the process of erection. The journals and bolt of clapper should be well oiled at intervals.

**Springs**

Springs are attached to our bells to prevent the clapper from resting on the bell after striking, their duty being to catch the clapper just before it reaches the bell, to permit of a stroke of sufficient force, and then to withdraw it and so prevent its clattering on the bell or any checking of the free vibration of the sound waves. These springs should be most carefully adjusted, as if too near to sides of bell they lack the power to throw the clapper back after its stroke and a second stroke will be the result. If too far from the bell sides they will be too rigid and will prevent the clapper striking with the requisite force. If upon testing the bell the springs be found out of order it should be swung over, mouth up, and held in that position and then by the use of a bar the springs should be forced out or in as required. The springs should not be touched unless obviously necessary as they are most carefully adjusted by us before shipment and they are not liable to derangement en route; if however, they should be bent or twisted they must be made perfectly true before bell is used.

**Attaching Rope**

After a bell has been mounted, tested, and the frame properly braced and fastened to belfry floor, it is ready for its operating rope. This should be attached to the wheel by passing it through the hole A, and securing it by means of a knot. Thence it is carried to a point directly under the center at B, and through the sheaves fastened to the floor, as shown in cut. This arrangement prevents the rope being thrown from the wheel should a bell turn completely over in ringing. With the very largest bells the extra friction resulting from the deflection of the rope through these sheaves (B) greatly increases the labor of ringing. In such cases the rope may be carried down through the floor in a straight line as per dotted line C, and the sheaves dispensed with.

For twenty-four and twenty-six inch bells, use three-eighth inch rope; for twenty-eight, thirty and thirty-two inch, one-half inch rope; for thirty-four, thirty-six, thirty-eight, forty and forty-two inch, five-eighth inch rope; for forty-four, forty-six, forty-eight and fifty inch, three-quarter inch rope, and for fifty-two and fifty-four inch, one-inch rope. The rope should not be larger nor longer than necessary, since increased weight encumbers the free swing of the bell.

**How to Ring a Church Bell**

In ringing church bells it is customary to swing the bell upward during six or eight strokes until the momentum throws the mouth directly upward, and then, after holding it in this position for several seconds, long enough for the other bells—if there be any others in the vicinity—to ring up and then to repeat this ringing as before, alternating with the other neighboring bells. After ringing a few minutes thus, it is usual to toll the bell either with the clapper or tolling hammer. Tolling with the clapper, while certainly requiring more skill is preferable as it secures a more musical tone than the graver ones awakened by the regular tolling hammer. When using the tolling hammer a short firm blow should be struck and the hammer dropped as quickly as possible as its continued contact with the bell after striking checks the vibration and produces a jarring and unpleasant sound. While the bell is being rung by the main rope, the hammer rope, if not directly under the ringer's eye, should be so secured that it cannot be pulled, as otherwise the hammer might be broken off or the bell dismounted.

**Proper Care of Bells**

The mountings should be examined occasionally to see if they are in proper condition; all nuts tight; the clapper, springs and leather in good order. When leathers become worn they should be promptly replaced, and if clapper becomes flattened a new one should be supplied. Journal bearings should be kept well oiled, and care taken that no oil, grease or paint fall on the bell as any accumulation of these will impair its performance. A bell may be shifted to a new position when desired by partially unscrewing the nuts and turning it to the desired point. When this is done care must be taken to adjust the springs and clapper precisely at right angles with the yoke and to screw all nuts down firmly, one by one, with a powerful wrench.

The mountings, and not the bell, should be kept well painted to protect them from rust.

OTTAWA, May 26th, 1921.

Sir,

Mr. Bennett, Public School Inspector, in a recent report on his inspection of the Kaboni Indian Day School, states as follows:

"To keep the building in good shape and protect from weather, the building should be painted. Some carpenter work, fixing some wear and tear needs to be done. Half a day would do it all. At the belfrey the rain comes in. Pails are used to catch it."

I will be pleased if you will furnish an estimate of the cost of having the building painted, and also how you would recommend the work to be done, whether by contract or day labour.

You should arrange to have the few minor repairs mentioned by the Inspector attended to, and the belfrey should be repaired in order to prevent leakage.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant furnishing an estimate of the cost of painting the Kaboni Indian Day School building and closets.

In reply, I beg to say that in view of the fact that it has been found necessary to curtail expenditure, it is considered that this painting may stand over for another year, and authority cannot be granted for having this painting done at the present time.

You should arrange, however, to have a few minor repairs required attended to. The belfrey should be repaired in order to prevent the rain from coming in.

Any repairs required should be completed as cheaply as possible, and you should forward properly receipted vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

These repairs should receive attention during the present summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Kaboni Indian Day School, states that the chimney seems to be blocked; furnace needs cleaning and new grates are required; also that some small repairs are needed, such as a catch on the boys' entrance and a lock on the cellar door.

You should see that both the chimney and furnace are placed in good condition, and that a lock and catch are placed on the doors mentioned. Ottawa, May 20th, 1924.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Kaboni Indian Day School, recommends that the floor of the classroom be oiled during the coming summer vacation. You may arrange to have this work done. The floor should be thoroughly scrubbed and dried before the oil is applied. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred for the purpose.

The Inspector also states that the furnace did not work satisfactorily, but that you had attempted to solve the difficulty. The furnace should be thoroughly overhauled and any defects remedied before it is required for next winter's use.

The Inspector further states that mosquito netting is required for the classroom windows. If you consider that window screens and a screen door are required, you may arrange for the purchase and installation of the same. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

Sir;

I have the honour to report that there should be a wood shed erected at the Kaboni Day School. It should be large enough to store a supply of furnace wood for a whole winter. It has always been a lady teacher in charge at this school and I find that it is impossible for her to carry on as janitor unless there is a winter's supply of fuel piled in under cover. There is ample room in the basement for a supply for the kitchen stove, but a very small amount or room for furnace wood. The cost of erecting a suitable shed would amount to approximately $200.

I might also say that the furnace in connection with the school building is in bad condition, the brick wall around the furnace will have to be taken down and the furnace removed in order to have the necessary repairs carried out. Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith a requisition by Miss Carmel McGuire for a supply of floor Oil, Bon Ami, Dutch Cleanser and Linoleum for her living quarters at the Kaboni Indian Day School. She is asking for to be furnished with a Football and two Base balls, and a supply of garden seeds.

Oil should be furnished for the class-room as it preserves the floor and helps to keep the dust down when sweeping. The kitchen floor has never been covered with linoleum as it is hardwood, but by covering it with an oil cloth, or linoleum, it would curtail labour for the teacher in the way of cleaning.

Miss McGuire thought of planting a flower garden in connection with the school. Her idea is quite in line with school work carried on in the white settlements, but among the Indians during the latter part of June, July and August, in the mid-summer holidays there is not any person to water and look after the flowers and I am afraid her project will not be a success.

The flag pole rope is worn out and should be replaced by a new one.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, April 9, 1931.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, enclosing a requisition from the teacher of the Kaboni Indian Day School for a supply of floor oil, linoleum, garden seeds, etc.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of 2 gallons oil and 1 quart turpentine for the classroom floors. The floors should first be thoroughly scrubbed and allowed to dry before the oil is applied. This work should be carried out at a time when it would not interfere with the classroom work. You may also purchase the quantity of linoleum required for the kitchen floor.

Regarding the garden seeds, if you consider that arrangements could be made for the proper care of the garden during the summer holidays without any expense to the Department, you may purchase and have delivered to the teacher the quantity of flower seeds asked for. You may also supply a garden rake.

Besides the above authorized supplies, you may also purchase 6 combs and the quantity of rope required for the school flag.

After you have obtained the above supplies, you should forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

A football and two playground balls will be forwarded to the teacher from here.

Your obedient servant,

R. J. Lewis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Manitowaning,
Ont.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.
